title: Open Now: Truist Foundation Grant for Nonprofits Building Career Pathways and Stronger Small Businesses
summary: The Truist Foundation is committed to building stronger communities through strategic philanthropy and partnerships. By investing in innovative nonprofit organisations, the Foundation supports programs and initiatives that create greater opportunity for adults especially in the areas of economic mobility and small business development. If your organisation is working to empower communities through sustainable, high-impact initiatives, the Truist Foundation grant program may be a valuable funding opportunity. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Areas of Focus The Truist Foundation prioritises projects and programs that align with two key pillars: 1. Building Career Pathways to Economic Mobility The Foundation supports initiatives that help adults gain skills, training, and access to opportunities that improve their economic outcomes and long-term financial stability. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); 2. Strengthening Small Businesses Funding is available for programs that help small businesses start, grow, and thrive especially those that contribute to community development and job creation. Types of Projects Funded The Foundation focuses on sustainable, one-time investments rather than ongoing operational expenses. Examples of eligible funding needs include: ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); Launch of new programs Curriculum development or expansion Equipment required to deliver programs Capital needs that directly support program delivery Capital Campaign Consideration Capital campaign requests may be eligible if: The project aligns with Truist Foundation s mission and priorities At least 60% of the fundraising goal has already been secured through donations and pledges Grant Cycles and Deadlines The Truist Foundation offers three annual grant cycles : March 31 Applicants notified in July July 31 Applicants notified in November November 30 Applicants notified in April Organisations are encouraged to plan their applications accordingly to align with these review periods. Why Apply for a Truist Foundation Grant? By partnering with the Truist Foundation, organisations gain: Funding for impactful, sustainable programs Support for community-driven economic development Strategic partnership with a mission-driven philanthropic institution Access to evaluation and learning resources to strengthen program outcomes How to Apply Nonprofit organisations that serve adults and align with the Foundation s focus areas can apply through the Truist Foundation s online grant portal. Application Steps: Submit your application via the online portal Deadline: 31st March 2026 After You Receive a Grant Successful applicants will be guided through the next steps of the partnership process. These include: Required Actions Sign and return the Grant Agreement via DocuSign Submit payment information through the Benevity secure portal Complete Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) reports on a quarterly, bi-annual, or annual basis depending on grant size Grantees will receive reminders and guidance for each reporting requirement. Additional Resources for Grantees Recipients will have access to a range of support materials, including: Grantee Guidebook Reporting requirements and timelines Grant acknowledgement guidance Payment submission instructions For any additional support, grantees can reach out to the Foundation through the provided contact channels. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); Final Thoughts The Truist Foundation grant program represents a powerful opportunity for nonprofits working to improve economic mobility and empower small businesses. If your organisation is developing innovative, sustainable solutions that uplift communities, consider applying in one of the upcoming grant cycles. Start preparing your application today and join a growing network of organisations building a better future for all. For more information about Grant, Visit Here The post Open Now: Truist Foundation Grant for Nonprofits Building Career Pathways and Stronger Small Businesses appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: Argentina Internship Program Summer 2026: A Fully Funded Global Experience for STEM Students in Data, AI & Operations
summary: The Argentina Internship Program Summer 2026 is a fully funded, immersive international internship designed for ambitious students who want to turn academic knowledge into real-world, career-ready experience. Running from June 15 to August 14, 2026 , this 9-week summer internship places selected participants inside Argentina s dynamic energy, technology, and industrial ecosystem. With structured projects in Data Analytics, Artificial Intelligence, Process Improvement, Industrial Technology, and Operational Optimization , this program is especially relevant for U.S. STEM students seeking hands-on exposure to complex, high-impact environments beyond the classroom. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Applications are reviewed on a rolling basis , meaning early applications have a stronger chance of selection. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); Why the Argentina Internship Program Stands Out This is not a shadowing or observation-based internship. Participants work on real projects, meet real deadlines, and are expected to deliver real results. From day one, interns are immersed in professional teams where ownership, feedback, and accountability matter. The program is fully funded , covering: International flights Accommodation Daily meals Health insurance Immigration and visa support In-country transportation While the internship is unpaid, the value lies in the depth of experience, global exposure, and the ability to leave with measurable, provable skills rather than just a line on a CV. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); Areas of Experience Participants may be placed across multiple functional areas, including: Engineering (Upstream and Downstream Operations) Technology, Data Artificial Intelligence Industrial Operations Process Optimization Finance Economics Sales Marketing Energy Transition Placements are carefully matched based on each participant s academic background, interests, and career goals. Meet the Companies Interns will work with leading organizations operating at scale in high-complexity environments, including: Aeropuertos Argentina , managing major airport operations where logistics, safety, and efficiency intersect daily CGC , a key player in Argentina s hydrocarbon exploration and production Honeywell , delivering advanced solutions across aerospace, automation, and industrial systems Tecpetrol , leading energy development across the region Tenaris , a global leader in industrial manufacturing for the energy industry A global commodities trading company connecting vital resources through infrastructure, logistics, and financing These environments demand precision, adaptability, and problem-solving under pressure exactly the skills global employers value. The True Learning Experience Participants learn by doing. Interns work inside professional teams, receive direct feedback, and collaborate across cultures. The experience rapidly builds independence, confidence, and global mindset qualities that differentiate candidates in competitive job markets. In addition to company placements, interns also: Connect with executives and industry leaders Visit universities and innovation hubs Experience Argentina s professional and cultural ecosystem beyond the workplace Life in Argentina Argentina offers far more than its global reputation for soccer. From world-class cities to diverse landscapes, the country combines cultural richness with professional intensity. Most activities are based in Buenos Aires , often called the Europe of Latin America, with additional site visits depending on company placement. How the Application Process Works Apply online by submitting your CV or LinkedIn profile Complete your full application if shortlisted Connect with the program team for guidance Get matched with the company that best fits your profile Complete final interviews with host companies Prepare for departure and begin your international journey Spanish is required to make the most of the experience, and stronger Spanish proficiency is a competitive advantage. Visa requirements vary by nationality, and full guidance is provided if you are selected. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); Important Dates Program Dates: June 15 August 14, 2026 Application Deadline: Rolling basis (early application strongly recommended) APPLY HERE For more information about this apportunity, click here . Discover more internship opportunities here . The post Argentina Internship Program Summer 2026: A Fully Funded Global Experience for STEM Students in Data, AI Operations appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: LSHTM MSc Scholarships and Funding Opportunities 2026/27
summary: The London School of Hygiene Tropical Medicine (LSHTM) has opened multiple funding and scholarship opportunities for the 2026/27 academic year , supporting students across key MSc programmes in global health, epidemiology, medical statistics, and related fields. Funding is available for both on-campus and distance learning programmes , with most deadlines falling in March 2026 . Eligibility, fee status, and funding coverage vary by course and scholarship. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); MSc Medical Statistics This programme focuses on statistical methods for medical and public health research, preparing graduates for roles in academia, research institutions, and health agencies. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); Available Scholarships: ISEP Postgraduate Training Fellowship (2026/27) Fee Status: Overseas students Deadline: 31 March 2026 MSc Medical Parasitology Entomology Designed for students interested in tropical medicine, vector-borne diseases, and infectious disease control. Available Scholarships: Royal Entomological Society Scholarship (2026/27) Fee Status: Home students Deadline: 25 March 2026 Mansfield Aders and Avebury Memorial Fund (2026/27) Fee Status: Home students Deadline: 25 March 2026 MSc Demography Health This programme explores population dynamics and their impact on health outcomes and policy. Available Scholarships: Basia Zaba Memorial Scholarship (2026/27) Fee Status: Home students Deadline: 25 March 2026 MSc Sexual Reproductive Health Policy and Programming Ideal for professionals aiming to influence sexual and reproductive health policy and programmes globally. Available Scholarships: MSc SRHPP Scholarships (2026/27) Fee Status: Overseas students Deadline: 22 March 2026 Distance Learning MSc Programmes Flexible postgraduate options for professionals balancing study with work or other commitments. Available Scholarships: LSHTM First Generation Scholarship (2026/27) Fee Status: See individual advert Deadline: 27 March 2026 Multiple MSc Programmes (Various Disciplines) These scholarships are not tied to a single course and can be used across several MSc programmes. Available Scholarships: LSHTM Next Generation Scholarships (2026/27) Fee Status: Home students Deadline: 27 March 2026 GSK Scholarships for Future Health Leaders (2026/27) Fee Status: Overseas students Deadline: 4 March 2026 LSHTM Fund Scholarship (2026/27) Fee Status: Overseas students Deadline: 4 March 2026 Important Notes for Applicants Applicants must meet the admission requirements for their chosen MSc programme. Each scholarship has specific eligibility and selection criteria. LSHTM regularly updates its funding list, and new opportunities may be added. Applications from Black, Asian, Ethnic Minority, and first-generation students are particularly encouraged. For more information about this apportunity, click here . Discover more scholarships and fundings opportunities here . The post LSHTM MSc Scholarships and Funding Opportunities 2026/27 appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: 2026 Funding Opportunities in Europe: BNP Paribas Banlieues Project (France) & ILGA-Europe Fund for Racial Justice Grants up to €25,000
summary: Two major 2026 funding opportunities are now open in Europe for grassroots organisations and community-led initiatives working on social inclusion, anti-discrimination, education, employment, civic space, and racial justice. The BNP Paribas Banlieues Project 2026 in France supports local associations working in Priority Districts of the City (QPV), while the ILGA-Europe Fund for Racial Justice 2026 provides grants of up to 25,000 to organisations led by racialised LGBTI communities across Europe. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Both calls aim to strengthen civil society, empower marginalised communities, and build long-term structural change. Below is a comprehensive guide covering eligibility, funding scope, timelines, and application processes for both opportunities. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); 1. BNP Paribas Banlieues Project 2026 Support for Local Associations in France Overview of the Banlieues Project Launched in 2006 by BNP Paribas and managed by the BNP Paribas Foundation, the Banlieues Project is a solidarity programme designed to support local associations operating in Priority Districts of the City (QPV) in France. Each year, BNP Paribas launches a call for applications to identify and support grassroots associations that combat exclusion and promote: ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); Access to education Professional integration and employment Entrepreneurship Social cohesion and living better together The project not only provides financial support but also strengthens visibility, institutional connections, and ecosystem integration for selected associations. Since its inception, the Banlieues Project has helped numerous associations scale their impact and gain national recognition. 2026 Key Dates Submission of Applications: 28 January 9 March 2026 Application Review: March June 2026 Decision Committee: June 2026 Fields of Action Supported Projects must align with the solidarity theme and fall under one or more of the following categories: ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); Access to Education Academic support Literacy programmes Cultural integration initiatives Digital inclusion Citizenship education Environmental awareness initiatives Access to Employment Professional integration programmes Vocational training Mentorship programmes Entrepreneurship support Improvement of Living Together Intercultural and intergenerational actions Strengthening social bonds Regional planning initiatives Ecological transformation projects Community-based solidarity efforts Who Can Apply? Eligible applicants are local associations operating within Priority Districts of the City (QPV) in France, including overseas territories. Associations must demonstrate: Active engagement in combating exclusion Strong local presence Commitment to education, employment access, or social cohesion Clear impact within priority neighbourhoods What Makes the Banlieues Project Unique? Beyond financial assistance, the programme: Promotes supported organisations within a wider institutional ecosystem Enhances visibility among public stakeholders Connects associations with the general public Strengthens long-term development capacity The programme recognises and amplifies everyday heroes working at the community level. Learn more and apply HERE . 2. ILGA-Europe Fund for Racial Justice 2026 Grants up to 25,000 Overview of the Fund The ILGA-Europe Fund for Racial Justice is the successor to the No One Left Behind Fund and focuses on supporting organisations led by racialised LGBTI communities in Europe. The Fund recognises that advancing LGBTI equality requires addressing racism as a structural force and strengthening racial justice activism within civic and political spaces. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(131); }); Through this call, ILGA-Europe will support up to 12 organisations with grants of up to 25,000 each for 12 months. Application Deadline 13 April 2026, 23:59 CEST Applicants will be informed of results during the week of 11 May 2026. What the Fund Supports Projects must run from 1 June 2026 to 1 June 2027 and may include: Creating or protecting civic and political space Strengthening community organising and solidarity Challenging oppressive systems and practices Shifting public narratives Organising public campaigns or cultural initiatives Mapping or documenting community needs tied to collective action Building cross-movement alliances The Fund encourages approaches combining: Care practices Direct organising Collective public engagement Funding Details Each selected organisation may receive: Up to 25,000 for 12 months Eligible budget lines include: Personnel costs Travel and event expenses External expertise Interpretation and translation Communication and outreach Administrative/core costs linked to project delivery There is no fixed percentage cap on personnel or consultancy costs if aligned with project objectives. Partnership Structure Selected organisations will participate in: Three online partner meetings One in-person meeting in Dublin (6 7 October 2026) Quarterly progress calls Interim report (November 2026) Final report (June 2027) Who Can Apply? The call is open to registered and non-registered organisations in Europe that: Are led by racialised LGBTI people Work for and with racialised LGBTI communities Non-registered groups must partner with a registered legal entity. Applicants must be ILGA-Europe member organisations by 1 June 2026 (or have membership applications under consideration by 1 April 2026). ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(132); }); Funding primarily supports EU-based organisations, with potential limited support for non-EU applicants if additional funding is secured. Learn more and apply HERE . Comparison of the Two 2026 Funding Opportunities BNP Paribas Banlieues Project: Focus: Local associations in French QPV areas Themes: Education, employment, social cohesion Geographic Scope: France (including overseas territories) Deadline: 9 March 2026 ILGA-Europe Fund for Racial Justice: Focus: Racialised LGBTI-led organisations Themes: Civic space, racial justice, LGBTI equality Geographic Scope: Europe (primarily EU Member States) Deadline: 13 April 2026 Both programmes strengthen grassroots organising and community-led change. For more global grant opportunities, visit HERE . The post 2026 Funding Opportunities in Europe: BNP Paribas Banlieues Project (France) ILGA-Europe Fund for Racial Justice Grants up to €25,000 appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: Fully Funded Local Business Journalism Fellowship 2026 in Washington, D.C. (Apply by March 23)
summary: The National Press Foundation (NPF) is now accepting applications for its Local Business Journalism Fellowship , a prestigious, expenses-paid, four-day professional training program designed to strengthen business reporting across the United States. Scheduled for April 26 29, 2026 , this intensive fellowship will bring 35 selected journalists to Washington, D.C. for in-depth briefings with economists, small business owners, policy leaders, and industry experts. The program is tuition-free , with airfare, hotel accommodations, and some meals fully covered. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); This fellowship is sponsored by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce , while NPF retains full editorial control over the program s content. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); Why This Fellowship Matters Small businesses employ nearly half of the U.S. workforce, yet they face mounting challenges in 2026, including economic uncertainty, labor shortages, housing pressures, artificial intelligence disruption, and the growing caregiver economy. This fellowship equips journalists with the knowledge, sources, and context needed to report accurately and impactfully on these issues in their communities. What Fellows Will Gain Participants will engage in exclusive, off-the-record briefings and discussions covering: Small business and economic trends Housing and labor market challenges The impact of artificial intelligence on businesses The caregiver economy Investigating businesses and nonprofit organizations Policies and practices that drive stability, innovation, and sustainable growth Attendance is mandatory for all sessions, ensuring a fully immersive learning experience. Program Details Location: Washington, D.C. Dates: April 26 29, 2026 Cost: Free (airfare, hotel, and some meals covered) Participants: 35 journalists Editors and supervisors must provide a letter confirming that selected reporters will be released from newsroom duties for the duration of the fellowship. Freelancers must submit a letter from an editor expressing interest in publishing work informed by the training. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); Commitment to Diversity The National Press Foundation strongly values diversity and encourages applications from journalists of color, reporters working in news deserts, and those from local and nonprofit news organizations. Journalists from all media formats are welcome. Application Deadline March 23, 2026, at 11:59 PM ET Incomplete or late applications will not be considered, and applications cannot be saved once started applicants are advised to prepare all required materials in advance. APPLY HERE For more information about this apportunity, click here . Discover more fellowship opportunities here . For technical questions, applicants may contact Celia Milch at celia@nationalpress.org The post Fully Funded Local Business Journalism Fellowship 2026 in Washington, D.C. (Apply by March 23) appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: Headstream Accelerator 2026: $30,000 Non-Dilutive Funding for Digital Youth Mental Health Startups in the U.S.
summary: The Headstream Accelerator 2026 (Cohort VI) is now accepting applications for its four-month, virtual-first program designed to support early-stage entrepreneurs building digital solutions that improve the mental well-being of teens particularly those at risk and from historically excluded communities. This highly competitive accelerator offers a $30,000 non-dilutive stipend , youth co-creation partnerships, expert mentorship, and direct access to investors and sector leaders. If you are building a tech-enabled product that supports youth mental health in education or healthcare settings, this opportunity could significantly accelerate your growth. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); What Is the Headstream Accelerator? The Headstream Accelerator is an impact-driven program focused on scaling digital innovations that enhance mental health outcomes for youth across the United States. The program is especially interested in solutions serving teens ages 13 19 , though pre-teen and college-aged youth solutions are also eligible. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); Unlike traditional accelerators that focus primarily on revenue growth and fundraising, Headstream emphasizes: Cultural relevance Youth voice integration Accessibility for historically excluded communities Sustainable impact models The program supports startups, social enterprises, nonprofits, research institutions, and other innovation-driven organizations with a U.S. market focus. Key Benefits of the Headstream Accelerator 2026 Participants selected for Cohort VI will receive a comprehensive support package designed to strengthen both product development and business sustainability. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); $30,000 Non-Dilutive Stipend Each selected venture receives $30,000 in non-dilutive funding , meaning founders retain full ownership of their company. The stipend is distributed at the end of the 16-week program. This funding can be used to: Advance product development Expand pilot programs Strengthen operational infrastructure Support market entry strategies Youth Co-Creation Partnership One of the most distinctive elements of the program is collaboration with youth through Headstream s Youth Co-Creator Club. Participants gain: Direct insight into teen user experience Feedback on cultural relevance Guidance on age-appropriateness Real-world validation of product features Embedding youth voices into product development ensures solutions are truly resonant, engaging, and impactful. Access to Expert Advisors and Investors Cohort members gain access to: A national network of expert advisors A community of mission-driven founders Potential investors and capital providers Sector leaders in education and healthcare This ecosystem creates strategic opportunities for partnerships, pilot testing, funding, and scaling. Coaching with FounderWell Participants receive: One-on-one coaching Group coaching sessions Structured growth guidance FounderWell provides practical, founder-centered support to strengthen leadership capacity, refine business models, and prepare for long-term growth. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); Who Should Apply? The Headstream Accelerator supports early-stage digital solutions advancing youth mental well-being, especially those serving historically excluded communities. You should apply if you: Have a functional prototype Are preparing to launch or scale Have a sustainable funding model Have a clear growth plan Are focused on youth mental health outcomes Are building a tech-enabled solution Idea-stage startups are not eligible. Required Selection Criteria To qualify, applicants must meet the following criteria: Clear impact on youth mental well-being Tech-enabled solution serving youth in the U.S. Preference for ages 13 19 (other youth groups eligible) Functional prototype already built Sustainable funding model Commitment to inclusivity U.S. market focus International applicants may apply if they have a U.S. presence or U.S. market focus . Eligible applicant types include: Startups Social enterprises Nonprofits Research institutions Hybrid organizations Revenue generation is not required, but sustainability is essential. Participant Expectations Selected participants must: Attend all virtual cohort sessions Participate in youth co-creation sessions Join advisor calls Attend the in-person kickoff event (July 28 30, 2026) Commit 2 5 hours weekly Actively integrate youth voices into product development The program runs virtually, making it accessible nationwide, with one required in-person kickoff event. 2026 Timeline Applications Open: January 15, 2026 Applications Close: March 15, 2026 Interviews: May 22 June 4, 2026 New Cohort Notified: Week of June 15, 2026 Virtual Program Start: Week of July 6, 2026 In-Person Kickoff: July 28 30, 2026 Program End: Week of November 2, 2026 Frequently Asked Questions Do I need to generate revenue? No. You must have a functional prototype, a sustainable funding model, and a growth plan. Are nonprofits eligible? Yes. Nonprofits are eligible as long as they demonstrate sustainability. Can solo founders apply? Yes. Part-time entrepreneurs and solo founders are eligible. Having collaborators or contractors is encouraged. When is the stipend provided? The stipend is distributed at the end of the 16-week program. Can I edit my application? Yes, until the application deadline. After March 15, 2026, submissions are final. What happens after applying? Applicants will be notified during the week of June 15, 2026. Selected applicants will be invited to interviews. Why the Headstream Accelerator Matters Youth mental health is a growing crisis in the United States. Digital innovation has the potential to expand access, reduce stigma, and improve mental health outcomes at scale. However, impact-driven startups often lack early-stage funding, strategic mentorship, and meaningful youth engagement. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(131); }); The Headstream Accelerator addresses these gaps by combining: Non-dilutive funding Youth-centered design Expert mentorship Cross-sector collaboration Sustainable growth strategies For founders committed to building inclusive, tech-enabled mental health solutions, this program offers both capital and credibility. For more information click here Apply here for more opportunities click here The post Headstream Accelerator 2026: $30,000 Non-Dilutive Funding for Digital Youth Mental Health Startups in the U.S. appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: Apply for a Funded Climate & Mental Health PhD at The University of Manchester (2026 Intake)
summary: The PDS HEAT-ID PhD project offers a unique opportunity to explore the mental health impacts of climate-related heat exposure in Indonesia one of the world s most climate-vulnerable regions. As global temperatures rise and extreme heat events become more frequent, understanding how heat affects mental health particularly anxiety and depression is increasingly urgent. This interdisciplinary research will generate robust, policy-relevant evidence on how heat exposure influences mental health outcomes, especially among socially and economically disadvantaged populations. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Institution: The University of Manchester Division of Nursing, Midwifery and Social Work Location: Manchester, United Kingdom Funding Type: Competition Funded PhD Project (Students Worldwide) Start Date: September 2026 Application Deadline: Monday, March 16, 2026 ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); About the Project Indonesia presents a compelling context for this research due to its: High baseline temperatures (average of approximately 27 C) Rapid urbanisation Significant social and economic inequalities Increasing frequency of extreme heat stress days (doubling from 10 to 18 days annually in recent decades) Despite growing concern, the relationship between heat exposure and mental health remains underexplored, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); Research Objectives This PhD aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of how heat exposure affects mental health through four key objectives: Evidence Synthesis: Review existing literature on heat exposure and its links to anxiety and depression, identifying mechanisms and research gaps. Quantitative Analysis: Measure associations between heat exposure and mental health symptoms using longitudinal population data. Health Inequalities: Examine differences across population groups based on age, gender, socioeconomic status, and geographic location. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); Mechanisms of Impact: Investigate pathways such as physiological stress, sleep disruption, fatigue, financial strain, and housing-related vulnerability. Research Methods The successful candidate will work with anodised data from the STAND project , which includes: Data from 19,236 adults (aged 18+) in Java Island Survey waves conducted in 2023 and 2025 Detailed mental health, socio-demographic, and behavioural data This dataset will be combined with high-resolution temperature indicators derived from climate simulations enhanced by artificial intelligence. Analytical approaches will include: Advanced epidemiological modelling Subgroup and inequality analyses Generalised structural equation modelling to examine causal pathways Policy Impact This research will contribute critical evidence to inform: Public health policy Urban planning strategies Climate adaptation frameworks By identifying vulnerable populations and mechanisms of impact , the findings will support targeted interventions to reduce the mental health burden of rising temperatures in Indonesia and other climate-affected regions. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(131); }); Supervisory Environment The PhD will be supervised by an interdisciplinary team with expertise in: Population mental health Environmental health and climate modelling Health inequalities Advanced quantitative and epidemiological methods Doctoral candidates will benefit from: Advanced research training Interdisciplinary seminars Academic publishing support Policy engagement opportunities Candidate Requirements Applicants should demonstrate: Strong quantitative background in epidemiology, statistics, public health, environmental health, psychology, economics , or related fields Experience with statistical programming (e.g., R, Stata, or Python ) Interest in climate change, environmental health, and mental health research Experience with large-scale or longitudinal datasets is advantageous but not required. Entry Requirements Applicants must: Hold (or expect to obtain) a First-class UK honours degree or international equivalent Ideally possess a Master s degree (Merit or Distinction) in a relevant quantitative discipline Provide evidence of quantitative data analysis skills Funding Benefits The President s Doctoral Scholar Award provides: Full tuition fee coverage A UKRI-rate stipend An additional 1,000 annual stipend enhancement Funding duration of 3.5 years Note: Candidates are responsible for relocation, visa, and healthcare surcharge costs. Application Process Interested candidates must contact the primary supervisor before submitting an application to discuss suitability. How to Apply Apply via the official application porta l You may apply for up to two projects under this scheme Submit the following required documents: Curriculum Vitae (CV) Supporting Statement Academic Certificates and Transcripts Incomplete or late applications will not be considered. Equality, Diversity Inclusion Equality, diversity, and inclusion are central to research and training at The University of Manchester . Applicants from all backgrounds are strongly encouraged to apply.Register Your Interest Prospective applicants can register interest to: Receive updates from the university Access additional guidance on PhD selection Track application progress through a Find APhD account Start your research career at the intersection of climate science, mental health, and public policy and contribute to evidence-based solutions for one of the most pressing global challenges of our time. Discover more PhD Opportunities Here . The post Apply for a Funded Climate Mental Health PhD at The University of Manchester (2026 Intake) appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: 14th TULIP International Summer School 2026 in France (Fully Funded)
summary: The 14th TULIP International Summer School 2026 is now open for applications, offering a unique, fully funded academic experience in France for students and early-career researchers from around the world. This prestigious summer school focuses on Biological interactions from genes to ecosystems and brings together interdisciplinary perspectives across biology, ecology, and evolution. Organized by LabEx TULIP , the program will run for 7 days , from June 27 to July 3, 2026 , at the Centre de Montagne de Germ Louron , located in the scenic French Pyrenees. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Why Apply for the TULIP Summer School 2026? This summer school is designed to foster high-level scientific exchange and collaboration in a fully immersive, English-speaking environment. Each year, only 24 participants are selected, ensuring close interaction with leading researchers and peers. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); Program Highlights Participants will engage in: Plenary lectures by supervising scientists Interactive workshops focused on building interdisciplinary research project proposals Scientific discussions spanning molecular biology to ecosystem-level interactions Dedicated time to explore the Pyrenees and strengthen professional networks Mornings are devoted to lectures, while afternoons focus on hands-on workshops. One full day is reserved for outdoor activities and informal exchanges. Financial Coverage The TULIP Summer School is fully funded , covering: Accommodation for the entire duration All meals during the program Transportation from Toulouse to the summer school venue Program activities and visits There is no registration fee and no IELTS requirement . However, participants must cover their travel costs to and from Toulouse. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); Important Deadline The application deadline is March 2, 2026 . Incomplete applications will not be considered, and selected candidates will be notified by the end of March 2026. Location Practical Information Venue: Centre de Montagne de Germ Louron, French Pyrenees Language: English Food: Local produce-based meals; vegetarian options available Accessibility: Accessible for participants with reduced mobility within venue limits How to Apply Applicants must complete the online application form and upload: A CV A cover letter Both documents must be submitted in PDF or DOC format. Application Form: APPLY HERE For more information about this apportunity, click here . Discover more summer school opportunities here . Contact Information For inquiries, contact: antoine.chehere@inrae.fr The post 14th TULIP International Summer School 2026 in France (Fully Funded) appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .

title: Food Justice for Kids Prize 2026: Up to $100,000 in Grants for U.S. Nonprofits, Tribes, and Schools Advancing Food Justice
summary: The Food Justice for Kids Prize 2026 is now open for applications and nominations, offering transformative grant funding of up to $100,000 per organization over two years . This national initiative supports nonprofits, Tribal entities, schools, and school districts across the United States and its territories that are working to ensure every child has access to nutritious, culturally relevant food both in schools and in their communities. Powered by Newman s Own Foundation , Humanitix , The Henry P. Kendall Foundation , and the Hunger to Health Collaboratory , the Prize aims to support innovative projects building a more just, inclusive, and sustainable food system for children. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(127); }); Why Food Justice for Kids Matters Across the United States, food insecurity remains a critical and urgent issue affecting millions of children. Today: ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(128); }); 1 in 5 children (14.1 million) live in households without consistent access to nutritious food. More than half of U.S. children do not consume enough fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. Food insecurity is strongly linked to developmental delays, anxiety, depression, and long-term chronic health conditions. For children to learn effectively, grow physically, and thrive emotionally, they must have access not just to food but to nutritious, culturally meaningful, and sustainable food systems . The crisis is even more pronounced in Indigenous communities. Centuries of land dispossession and disruption of traditional food systems have led to disproportionately high levels of food insecurity among Native American youth, alongside increased risks of obesity and Type 2 diabetes. Revitalizing Indigenous food sovereignty is therefore central to advancing food justice nationwide. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(129); }); The Food Justice for Kids Prize envisions a country where all children: Access nutritious, culturally relevant foods Learn about sustainable food systems Grow, gather, and cook food Experience nourishment physically, mentally, emotionally, and spiritually This is the second call for applications following the inaugural 2024 Prize recipients. Grant Amount and Funding Structure Selected organizations may receive: Up to $100,000 total Distributed over a two-year period Flexible funding (within program guidelines) Support from multiple co-funders Up to 14 organizations may be awarded. Funding can support program implementation, policy advocacy, and systemic change initiatives aligned with the Prize s mission. Focus Areas for 2026 1. Indigenous Food Justice This focus area supports projects and policy work that: Advance food sovereignty for Indigenous children and youth Reconnect children with traditional food systems Support gathering, growing, and cooking Indigenous foods Restore cultural knowledge related to food Organizations working with Native communities to rebuild local food systems, preserve cultural practices, and empower youth leadership are strongly encouraged to apply. 2. Nutrition Education School Food This focus area supports projects and policy work that: Provide nutrition education to children and youth Promote culturally relevant and healthy meals in schools Integrate local food systems into school programs Improve access to school meal programs Encourage hands-on food growing and cooking initiatives This category is not strictly limited to in-school programs; community-based initiatives aligned with school food access are also considered. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(130); }); Who Can Apply? Eligible applicants include: Nonprofit organizations Tribal entities Schools School districts Applicants must demonstrate: Alignment with food justice principles Innovation in approach Evidence of measurable impact Clear project goals (including SMARTIE-aligned goals) A feasible and well-structured budget Organizations do not need to be nominated to apply. Nominations do not increase selection chances but help spotlight innovative work. Key Dates and Timeline Nomination Period: February 17 April 21, 2026 (1:00 PM ET) Application Period: February 17 April 28, 2026 (1:00 PM ET) Informational Webinars: February 27, 2026 3:30 PM ET March 25, 2026 4:00 PM ET Finalists Notified: End of July 2026 Virtual Interviews: Week of August 10, 2026 Award Announcement Grant Disbursement: September/October 2026 Prize Recognition Event: October 29, 2026 at the Hunger to Health Collaboratory 2026 Fall Summit in Washington, DC What Makes a Strong Application? Successful applications typically demonstrate: Clear and innovative program design Measurable outcomes and evidence of impact Community-rooted leadership Cultural responsiveness Sustainable long-term change potential A realistic, well-documented budget Policy-focused initiatives are welcome, particularly those improving systemic access to nutritious and culturally relevant food for children. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(131); }); Applicants selected as finalists will participate in virtual interviews before final awards are determined. How to Apply or Nominate Organizations can: Submit a direct application before April 28, 2026 Nominate an organization before April 21, 2026 Informational webinars are available to guide applicants through the process, clarify eligibility, and answer technical questions. Building the Next Generation of Food Citizens The Food Justice for Kids Prize is more than a grant it is an investment in the next generation of food citizens. By supporting projects that combine access, education, culture, and sustainability, the Prize contributes to reshaping how children experience food in schools and communities across the United States. Organizations dedicated to transforming food systems for children are encouraged to apply and be part of this growing movement for equity, health, and cultural restoration. ezstandalone.cmd.push(function () { ezstandalone.showAds(132); }); For more information click here Apply here Discover more grants opportunities here The post Food Justice for Kids Prize 2026: Up to $100,000 in Grants for U.S. Nonprofits, Tribes, and Schools Advancing Food Justice appeared first on Opportunities for Youth .
